name: ShaderFormat
comment:
Defines a shader asset to load.

This corresponds roughly to the shader specification within the OpenGL Transmission Format (glTF) with the addition of a field that can hold the source code.

name.name: name
name.comment:
The name of the resource.

This should be globally unique.

url.name: url
url.comment: The url for the resource shader source.

hasSource.name: hasSource
hasSource.comment: Whether the source code is already loaded.

reference.name: reference
reference.comment: Creates an instance of the lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormat where the data is in another instance.

fromJson.name: fromJson
fromJson.comment: Creates an instance of the lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormat class from JSON data.

parseList.name: parseList
parseList.comment:
Parses a list containing lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormats.

Returns a dart-core.Map containing the lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormats where the lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormat.name is the key value.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormat.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

isReference.name: isReference
isReference.comment:
Whether the instance just refers to data defined elsewhere.

If the value is true then the lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormat.name should be used to find the instance with the actual data; otherwise the instance will contain all the data required.

name.name: name
name.comment:
The name of the resource.

This should be globally unique.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormat.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormat.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormat.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormat.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormat.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of lithium_ion/lithium_content.ShaderFormat.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
